Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: CDS&E: Computationally-Guided Development of Chromatographic Phases with Improved Retention Characteristics and of Sustainable Mobile Phases
Award.AbstractNarration: With support from the Chemical Measurement & Imaging program, and co-funding from the Interfacial Engineering program, Professor Siepmann and his group at the University of Minnesota-Twin Cities together with collaborators Mark Schure at Kroungold Analytical and Stephanie Schuster at Advanced Materials Technology are investigating processes used to separate the components of chemical mixtures and enable their analysis. Specifically, they are using advanced simulations to obtain a molecular-level understanding of chromatographic separation processes. “Separation science plays a critical role in maintaining our standard of living and quality of life,” as recently emphasized by the National Academies in a report entitled "A Research Agenda for Transforming Separation Science." Chromatography is an important approach to separations that exploits differences in the interactions of various chemicals with particles packed into a tube (a chromatographic column). Small differences in these interactions get magnified as the mixture passes through the chromatographic column enabling one compound to move more quickly through the column than another and thus, separate. This university-industry team is working to improve understanding of how modifications of the particle surfaces and the use of environmentally benign solvents impact the separation, thereby enabling improved chemical separation systems. This partnership is advancing the education and training of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students, with special efforts made to recruit students from traditionally underrepresented groups in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics. This effort has relevance to advanced manufacturing as separations is one of the most expensive and time-consuming aspects of the production of industrial scale chemicals.<br/><br/>The underlying principles of liquid and supercritical fluid chromatography are inherently complex, being dictated by the interplay of the sample with the stationary phase (porous solid substrate and bonded ligands) and the mobile phase (often a mixture of solvents). The Siepmann group and Kroungold Analytical are using Monte Carlo and molecular dynamics simulations with enhanced-sampling algorithms and transferable molecular-mechanics force fields to model and characterize interactions in hydrophilic stationary phases including zwitterionic phases; novel hydrophobic stationary phases with limited flexibility and wettability tuned by the addition of hydrophilic compounds; and supercritical carbon dioxide and hot, compressed water mobile phases. The team is also utilizing coarse-grained models to investigate retention of block copolymers in superficially porous particles. Advanced Materials Technology is leading an effort to carry out synergistic chromatographic measurements. The development of both stationary phases with improved retention characteristics and sustainable mobile phases is being advanced through the molecular-level insights derived from this work.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chromatography is one of the principal methods for the analysis and separation of organic and pharmaceutical molecules and of synthetic and biological macromolecules. Chromatography involves a stationary phase that analyte molecules interact with and get retained to different degrees, allowing for separation, and a mobile phase or solvent that transports analytes through the device.  Due to the complexity of chromatographic systems and the lack of atomistic information, however, many fundamental questions on chromatographic retention processes remain unanswered.  Understanding how molecular-level interactions influence separation, i.e., the retention mechanism, is instrumental for improving the performance of existing chromatographic systems and for aiding in the development of future separation technologies.  The collaborative academic-industry research team led by Ilja Siepmann (University of Minnesota), Mark Schure (Kroungold Analytical), and Stephanie Schuster (Advanced Materials Technology) utilized expertise in molecular simulation, synthesis, and characterization to advance knowledge in two focus areas:

Elucidating Structure and Retention in Hydrophilic Liquid Interactions Chromatography (HILIC)

HILIC refers to stationary phases that are water-wettable and permit mobile phases that are high in organic solvent content (e.g., acetonitrile) and with a minor water content; HILIC is advantageous for the separation of complex polar molecules, such as many pharmaceutical compounds. The HILIC stationary phases provide a large fraction of hydroxyl groups or other strong hydrogen bond/donor acceptor moieties (e.g., surface silanols, sSiOH) that interact via hydrogen-bonding with water and analyte molecules. The molecular simulations allow us to separate contributions from the stationary phase and the mobile phase to retention. Non-polar groups are found to interact more favorably with the mobile phase than the stationary phase (i.e., reducing retention), whereas the reverse holds for polar groups. The simulations also reveal that water molecules are enriched at the stationary phase surface, but do not prevent analyte molecules from interacting directly with sSiOH groups (see Image HILIC).

Elucidating Structure and Retention in Supercritical Fluid Chromatography (SFC)

Use of a supercritical-fluid mobile phase increases the speed of analysis and allows for more facile recovery of the solvent, i.e., reducing the environmental burden compared to liquid chromatography. For commonly used stationary phases with long non-polar hydrocarbon chains (e.g., C18 alkyl ligands), we observe that the SFC solvent leads to a swelling of the bonded-chain region with less tilted C18 ligands compared to reversed-phase liquid chromatography (RPLC) conditions (see Image SFC). For nonpolar methylene (CH2) segments, the SFC mobile phase is a much stronger solvent than the RPLC mobile phase and, hence, the retention increment of a CH2 group is much smaller in SFC. For a polar hydroxyl (OH) group, the stationary C18 phase at RPLC conditions is more favorable than at SFC conditions because the more significant adsorption of water and methanol for the RPLC system make the stationary phase more polar with a higher concentration of accessible hydrogen-bonding sites for the OH groups of the analytes. Of course, the RPLC solvent provides an even more favorable environment for the OH groups, while the SFC mobile phase is a much weaker solvent. As a consequence, an OH group increases retention in SFC but decreases retention in RPLC.

Research supported by this NSF award afforded, for the first time, a detailed molecular view into retention in HILIC and SFC and into how common stationary phase materials interact with the corresponding mobile phases and are modified by addition of co-solvent (i.e., mobile-phase modifier). These insights are stimulating the thinking for selecting columns and improving stationary phase materials. Chromatographic phases with improved retention characteristics will fill major needs of the chemical, pharmaceutical, and bio-technology industries. Replacing water/organic mobile phases with greener mobile phases will reduce waste and make chromatographic separations more sustainable.

This university-industry partnership has advanced the education and training of two graduate and two undergraduate students by allowing for extensive interactions with industrial researchers and experiences with real-world applications. In addition, a high school student participated remotely during summer 2021. Three of these five junior researchers belong to groups underrepresented in the STEM fields.
